## And thus the 1,000 True Fans thesis eventually manifests.

In 2008, Kevin Kelly wrote one of the most seminal contributions in culture tech. The founding editor-in-chief of Wired wrote that, in the internet age:

> `â€œTo make a living as a craftsperson, photographer, musician, designer, author, animator, app maker, entrepreneur, or inventor you need only thousands of true fans.â€`

A thousand dedicated fans who love your niche. Sound familiar? 

So what took so long?

Itâ€™s certainly the case that the technology of the era made this difficult. Kelly hoped that the internet would be the ultimate matchmaker. Bring the creators and the consumers online, and they will find each other. To an extent, they did, especially in the early days of the internet: in 2008, writing about 1000 True Fans looked sensible. But it was still pretty hard: you could publish your own content, but without mass-market services like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, that helped you discover, it was tough to find or be found.

The introduction of these services, monoliths to be, helped in one sense: it was a lot easier for people to find you on the internet. But the price for this matchmaking was almost everything: Facebook and Instagram take almost 100% of all the revenue creators see on their platforms; YouTube takes 45%; Spotify paid an average of merely Â£700 to each artist last year[9](#footnote-9). These monoliths do the matching, but make it virtually unaffordable to create in the first place.

It was a vibe shift, not a technological one, that struck the first blow to this impoverished paradigm. Twitch, Kickstarter, Patreon, Substack, amongst many others, are all services built for creators to cater for the dedicated fans of their niche; all built amidst the community-centric vibe shift born in the 2010s. Well before the 2020 crypto bull run, a16z heralded a [100 True Fans model](https://future.a16z.com/1000-true-fans-try-100/) in 2020[10](#footnote-10), arguing that this was made possible with even more niche services from Podia, Teachable, and Kajabi. (These companies *all* help people sell educational courses, which undermines the argument to an extent, but you only need 250 fans paying Â£20/$25 per month to earn \~3x the average UK salary or [$75,000](https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2019628,00.html#:\~:text=no%20matter%20how%20much%20more), so you get the picture.) **With the alignment of technology and the vibe, the impoverished paradigm of community-stricken creatorship is collapsing.**

### Blockchain is a game-changer for this dynamic

*Youâ€™re reading on Mirror, so you probably know all this; you could easily skip to the next phrase in bold.*

In the early 2020s, new technologies like blockchain, distributed ledgers, and cryptocurrencies really came in vogue. A distributed ledger is triple-entry bookkeeping. [Double-entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping) bookkeeping was invented in medieval Italy: two parties to a transaction would both record it, giving you more data about your business and more verifiable figures, making it easier to trade and pursue enterprise.

Eight centuries later, distributed ledgers are triple-entry bookkeeping: as well as the seller and buyer, *every participant in the economy* makes a record of the transaction, and every participant is using the same, enormous, book. Blockchain is the technology of how you add to this book and run software with it, and cryptocurrency is one use case: the ledger essentially records how much currency you own, which everyone verifies. Obviously Iâ€™m simplifying, but Iâ€™ll refer to these technologies as â€˜web3 techsâ€™[11](#footnote-11).

The significance of blockchain becomes clear upon interrogating why Facebook, YouTube, *et al.* can take such high take rates on creators. One side is [discovery](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/infinite-scroll/what-the-creator-economy-promises-and-what-it-actually-does#:\~:text=no%20one%20finds%20a%20person%20on%20patreon%3B%20you%20go%20there%20after%20you%E2%80%99ve%20found%20them): you rarely *find* creators on Patreon. This happens, still, on big social networks. Everyone is on these platforms (well, not Facebook) and when you consume on these platforms frequently, theyâ€™re experts in figuring out what content youâ€™ll click on next; big data, [Markov chains](https://towardsdatascience.com/introduction-to-markov-chains-50da3645a50d#:\~:text=predict%20weather%20for%20days%20to%20come%2C%20based%20on%20what%20the%20current%20weather%20state%20is%20at%20the%20time), etc. There are some problems with this, mainly that you get served addictive content rather than niches that you want to engage deeply in, but generally they do this job pretty well, and web3 techs donâ€™t hugely change this.

But there are a lot of platforms for discovery â€” this isnâ€™t the competitive moat it once was. People use Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, and much more, in addition to the discovery platforms weâ€™ve called out above; as mentioned, most people have moved beyond Facebook. Creators could just move to whichever discovery network takes the smallest cut of their revenue. Apart from one thing: they canâ€™t. Everything youâ€™ve ever uploaded to Spotify and all the followers youâ€™ve earnt on Insta: the discovery platform manages this, and you canâ€™t take your community with you. So itâ€™s impossible to leave without starting all over again. And hence discovery networks [squeeze](https://stratechery.com/2015/niches-problem-subscription-services/) creators for revenue.

And hence, the game-changer. Because just like with your cryptocurrency, you can store your [writing](https://mirror.xyz/), your [music](https://sound.xyz/), your [art](https://opensea.io/), your [videos](https://d.tube/), your [followers](https://lens.xyz/), on a distributed ledger, or â€œon chainâ€. As [LBRY](https://lbry.io/) puts it: â€œLBRY does to publishing what Bitcoin did to money.â€ Just like with your currency, everyone participating in the economy agrees that â€œyes, [Leo](https://app.ens.domains/name/leosn.eth/details), you wrote this blogâ€. Sites like Spotify and Instagram donâ€™t manage your songs and your followers because these songs and follower relationships are stored on chain, and Spotify is reduced to one of many organisations competing to merely display this content in the best way, and help you discover new content as well. Creators are not beholden to any of them â€“ and neither are consumers[12](#footnote-12).

So now the community economy is fully on the way because finally, **dedicated participants in a niche community can meaningfully support their creators**. When people are deeply engaged in something they care about, even the original consumers become contributors, and weâ€™ll start to see vibrant ecosystems formed around niches and creators. Greg Isenberg explores the [Loot ecosystem](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/heres-what-the-future-of-nfts-looks?s=r#:\~:text=it%E2%80%99s%20an%20ecosystem%20not%20just%20an%20nft), an NFT project upon which creators have realised myriad different ideas; [Jenkins the Valet](https://www.jenkinsthevalet.com/how-it-works) is a great example of community-led storytelling, which will become a category-defining cultural genre in the 2020s, on par with â€˜artâ€™ and â€˜literatureâ€™. [Jadyn Violet](https://twitter.com/jadynviolet), a musician, told me that â€œIâ€™ve never got this much interaction on my art before.â€ He's been spending his time building new ideas to engage his community, spending time speaking with his fans, and making more music â€” this is what his fans love him for.

Business people often talk about the Minimum Viable Product your business needs before you start selling. The MVP isnâ€™t dead, but all businesses (not just creators) will soon require a [Minimum Viable Community](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uPRruLfZoU&t=2s) to make a mark in their market[13](#footnote-13).

What will underlie all of these communities are tokens of membership, probably tiered, which tie a community together. Theyâ€™ll be non-fungible, which means theyâ€™ll be unique and personalisable, thus allowing for deeper engagement. **Consumers get dedicated community and deeper value in a niche they care about; creators are finally rewarded fairly for their work.**

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for â€˜web3 in vogueâ€™ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldnâ€™t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) Iâ€™m simplifying a lot; this isnâ€™t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, itâ€™s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, itâ€™s every computer server; and itâ€™s not every computer server, itâ€™s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterinâ€™s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation â€” which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I donâ€™t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Problem Solving & Storytelling
body:
Some thoughts on why we're so polarized and incapable of constructive dialogue...

Human experience comes down to two things: problem solving and storytelling.

Problem solving is the cybernetic process of communication and control in the pursuit of goals.

Storytelling is the sense-making of our experience as problem solvers through goal-directed behavior.

Cybernetics is the idea that in the pursuit of some goal (docking a boat) we have to constantly adapt to our environment (wind, rain, tide) and adjust course (steer) to achieve that goal.

What we take in and how we react to it is a circular feedback process, and we judge our success by how close or far away we are from our goal. This process operates at every level of life â€” the goals just shift based on local context and conditions.

At the human level, each of us pursue our own goals and sense-make for ourselves. We individually construct an interpretation of our experience according to our own central nervous system and consciousness.

Itâ€™s only in relation to other human beings that we have to contend with the goals of other individuals. And itâ€™s there where shared or competing goals are determined.

Socially, weâ€™re aided by shared languaging (the totality of our intercommunications) and the emergent culture surrounding us, which further scaffolds, frames, and constrains our individual experience of sense-making.

Our personal realities are relative, subject to the localized information available to oneâ€™s consciousness in each moment. But through languaging and conversation, we explore our intersubjective experiences of the world together.

Conversation is used to explore potential solutions to perceived problems. If an intersubjective, shared meaning can be established, a foundation for collaborative sense-making and storytelling can be built upon. Agreement might be found.

However, if the â€œmaps of meaningâ€ arenâ€™t agreed upon, the definition of the â€œproblemâ€, defined as oneâ€™s distance from the imagined goal, also canâ€™t be agreed upon and collaborative progress wonâ€™t be made.

The conversation will be deemed unproductive and impractical relative to oneâ€™s goal and violence will be inevitable.

When each partyâ€™s perspective is based on the belief that â€œfactsâ€ exist, independent of observers, it leads to entrenched positions. Reason no longer works.

New â€œfactsâ€ aren't accepted because the framing of those facts is entangled in the subjective scaffolding of the individual and the emergent cultural context theyâ€™re embedded within.

The other observer is embedded in a different â€œreality.â€ The information of their intersubjective experience is only accessible to them and like-minded others.

Good faith conversation between parties with opposing viewpoints remains our only hope for resolution, but no shared agreement should be expected.

The distance between consciousnesses and their sense-making, the perceived problems to be solved, and the culture that enmeshes these experiences, is too great.

But we have to keep trying.

title: How does Frax Finance Works?
body:
## What is FRAX?

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Gzsf4rZ9_j_qzQ7WhRiAw.jpeg?height=721&width=1281)

Frax is a decentralized fractional stablecoin. This means, itâ€™s partially collateralized with on-chain crypto (USDC) and the other bit is backed by an algorithm.

The stablecoins market is very well established. How does Frax add a flavor to it? Letâ€™s understand stablecoins first.

The goal of any stablecoin is simpleâ€” maintain its peg to 1 USD. However, things get fiercely complex to achieve this simple goal.

Numerous methods like fiat collateralization, commodity backing, crypto collateralization, and complex computer algorithms have been used in the past. Here are some live results:

DAI is over collateralized.

USDT is fiat-backed but centralized. *[USDT has been frozen](https://cointelegraph.com/news/tether-blacklists-39-ethereum-addresses-worth-over-46-million)* in the past.

UST was completely algorithm-backed. However, the faith has been lost in stablecoins with its *[recent spiral death](https://www.forbes.com/sites/rahulrai/2022/05/17/the-death-spiral-how-terras-algorithmic-stablecoin-came-crashing-down/#:\~:text=This%20selling%20pressure%20on%20UST,inflationary%20loop%20in%20LUNA's%20supply)*.

On the contrary, FRAX is neither a hundred percent Fiat nor algorithm backed, only collateralized by the given fraction called collateralization ratio.

This collateralization ratio is however not decided by the Frax protocol. The collateral can go in any direction in long run. It only adjusts to keep the peg of FRAX to $1.

## Minting & Stability of FRAX

### Minting

The *[FRAX minting process](https://docs.frax.finance/minting-and-redeeming)* is kept simple. To mint one FRAX (worth $1) a collateral amount (only USDC) along with Frax governance token (FXS) within the parameters of the pre-determined collateral ratio is locked in Frax Finance treasury.

For instance, if the collateral ratio is 85 percent, 0.85 percent of USDC with 0.15 percent of FXS can be locked in Frax Protocol to mint one FRAX. The same can be redeemed, if the FRAX is returned to its protocol, the user is given back the locked assets (USDC and FXS).

### Stability

Say the price of Frax breaks its peg either way up or down. The stability can be restored. The process is fairly incentivized for users to even care about it

For instance, if the Frax trades above a dollar, Arbitrageurs can deposit USDC and FXS only worth a dollar in the required collateral ratio, to mint one FRAX token. This token then can be traded in the open market and the user can bag the difference.

For the other way around, if Frax trades below a dollar, arbitrageurs can buy from the open market at less than a dollar, and then redeem it to bag the USDC & FXS in a collateralized ratio worth one dollar.

However, the collateral ratio is entitled to change according to market demands. Say, you deposited 80 USDC and 20 dollarsâ€™ worth of FXS to mint 100 FRAX. Upon redemption, you may receive deposited assets in different ratio as it is subject to change.

## FXSâ€“ The Governance Token & Value accrual

At the genesis of FXS tokenomics, the supply was capped at a total of 100 million.

With every FRAX mint, the collateralized FXS is burnt. This creates a limited supply of its governance token. As the usage of Frax ups, the supply of FXS is reduced, creating more value for its governance token and to its holders.

Hey, the holders can pool FXS in liquidity pairs like FXS/FRAX, and FXS/ETH on Uniswap to earn a small cut for gas collected on every swap.

With more veFXS comes more Voting powers. It follows a similar voting escrow model that is popular amongst other DeFi protocols.

Users can lock up their FXS in return for veFXS for up to 4 years, the higher the locking period the maximum rewards, yeah, yeah, you get it. The reward for veFXS seems promising:

* Governance rights
* Special boost rewards
* AMOs profits

*[Frax AMOs](https://app.frax.finance/amos)* are programmatically designed to move the collateral USDC to other DeFi ecosystems to efficiently enhance the profits without actually breaking the FRAX peg to $1. The profits are then used to rebuy Frax and burn it, or directly lend profits to veFXS holders.

In any other case if the collateralization ratio is increased, requiring more USDC collateral. The AMO reverses and deposits the USDC back until FRAX restores confidence.

Frax has implemented several important AMOs, each AMO works hard (lol, computer programs) to bring maximum profits to the Frax treasury.

* FRAX 1559
* Collateral investor
* Curve AMO
* Uniswap V3
* Frax lending

The majority of profits are brought in by the collateral investor AMO which is about $70 million, while other AMOs also have a fair share in accruing the profits.

## veFXS Upgrade: Frax, Convex, and Curve wars\*\*\*\*

The story of reaps & rewards goes further with their *[partnership with Convex](https://convexfinance.medium.com/december-update-protocol-expansion-cvx-eth-incentive-migration-2c9327b48259#0a3b)*. From here on things are a bit complex, if, in simpler terms, itâ€™s more money for veFXS holders. Before we head on to how this partnership benefits FRAX and its holders, letâ€™s understand Convex Protocol first.

Decrypting in 3â€¦ 2â€¦ 1â€¦ Go!

Soon after its launch,\* \*Convex Protocol gained traction in the DeFi space. Hereâ€™s whyâ€” Simplicity and more rewards. The user couldnâ€™t ask for moreâ€” unless itâ€™s even more money.

Convex simplifies now what is known as the Curve wars on its user's behalf.

It soon began accruing CRV and veCRV, and by the first half of 2021, it became the largest holder of veCRV.

This is where Curve Wars gets intÃ©ressant. With more veCRV comes more Voting powers. Wait, but howâ€™s voting power gonna helpâ€” unless itâ€™s about money.

Every 10 days, the curve emissions are decided by the veCRV holdersâ€” the voters. That which pool shall benefit maximum from the emission.

Curve emission is the highness term for, the distribution of swap fees collected on curve protocol to various liquidity poolers.

Hereâ€™s what partnership does, Frax holds 19% of convex becoming the largest holder than any in the space. This ultimately bestows Frax the governance powers of the Curve protocol.

Hereâ€™s what partnership does for veFXS holders. Users can lock the same in return for cvxFXS. This is however an irreversible deal. The protocol in future plans to introduce FPI (Frax Price Index) that will be airdropped to every cvxFXS holder.

The other exit strategy cvxFXS/FXS pool is being planned. However, at the time of writing this gem, the development is still in the very early stage, and the writer is thrilled about the upcoming Elvis film.

## Final thoughts on Frax Protocol

Thatâ€™s all fellas you donâ€™t need a conclusion or final thoughts on Frax protocol. Nope, you donâ€™t need it at all. All you need is love. Hereâ€™s love for you, &Peace.

title: Community and the niche market vibe shift
body:
***Brands and creators that build for niche and dedicated communities will win the 2020s.***

Iâ€™ve seen a lot more sweetshops around recently. Specifically, these Victorian-themed tuckshops and sweet connoisseurs, plucked from two hundred years prior and plopped in the middle of a high street that doesnâ€™t quite know how to welcome its new tenant. One of the sweet shops near me plasters â€˜Toys, Trains, Treatsâ€ on dated storefront panelling; itâ€™s the shop you thought your grandparents went to when they were young, except the steam trains on sale are battery powered.

This wasnâ€™t just a Baaderâ€“Meinhof [phenomenon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency_illusion), where upon seeing something once you perceive it everywhere. During the first year of the pandemic, an extra [73](https://www.mylondon.news/news/uk-world-news/i-visited-londons-new-dangerous-22961908#:\~:text=73%20more%20sweet%20shops%20in%20the%20uk%20compared%20with%202020) sweetshops popped up in the UK, net, according to the Local Data Company. Thatâ€™s not a huge number, but itâ€™s pretty significant given the broader lockdown context; the total number of clothing shops fell by 1,236 in the same period[1](#footnote-1). The shop near me was set up in September â€˜21. It begs the question: whatâ€™s so special about sweet shops?

I had spent my Saturday morning at Waterstones buying some books, at the sweet shop questioning the shop assistant, and now Iâ€™m writing about it on Substack. In days gone by, I would have bought my physical items at Sainsburyâ€™s and, in comparison to today, where I have my Substack and my main [website](https://www.leonasskau.co.uk/), all my digital publishing would be through the same technology stack, probably Wordpress.

Sweets are nice, but the real difference is the existence of a shop that will focus all of its resources on their specific niche product. I bought some weird caramel chocolate flakes that defy description, but they were excellent. I certainly paid a premium, but next time I want sweets, Iâ€™ll go there again, because *they know their product*; I just bought what the shop assistant recommended. At Waterstoneâ€™s, I picked up [Train Dreams](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/13/train-dreams-denis-johnson-review) because I told the manager I was after contemporary fiction; I use Substack because itâ€™s built for writers[2](#footnote-2). **What makes these businesses special is that they serve *niche markets in which they can give people much deeper value.***

![I mean, you get what Iâ€™m saying, despite the weird animojis, right? (HelloDorking)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xRINH9-26W7ZvCggFpXtm.jpeg?height=2438&width=3024)

## Unbundling into niches

Bundling and unbundling are [not new concepts](https://hbr.org/1999/03/unbundling-the-corporation). Itâ€™s a pretty simple convection model: you start with a business, over time you add more products, services, and features, and then you get bloated, do everything â€˜kinda wellâ€™, until a niche competitor comes along and does *one* of your services *really really well*, and bit by bit you get pieced apart. The [complexity convection](https://every.to/divinations/complexity-convection-765851) is a pattern that cannot be unseen. 

People have observed this happening to our contemporary digital landscape for about a decade, beginning in practice much earlier. Craigslist was [unbundled](https://thegongshow.tumblr.com/post/345941486/the-spawn-of-craigslist-like-most-vcs-that-focus) into many things, including Reddit, which is now being [unbundled](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/the-guide-to-unbundling-reddit?s=r) into many more things, like Nextdoor. In the language of [a16z](https://a16z.com/2019/09/11/platforms-verticals-unbundling/), the famed tech investors: platforms get unbundled into verticals, which turn into platforms, at which point the cycle resumes, and all of a sudden Iâ€™ve turned into a strategy writer[3](#footnote-3). 

Iâ€™m not the first to herald this unbundling in the physical world either. Peter Day [wrote](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=Economy%2C%20%20almost%20a,speed%20and%20efficiency.) an excellent essay predicting â€œthe heartbeat economy, almost a concierge approach to customers,â€ in 2013:

> `â€œThis would be a worryingly intimate relationship for many businesses, but one which might provide a new kind of rewarding marketplace if they dared to be far closer to their customers' individuality.â€`

He wrote about it in the BBC, but today he would write on his own blog.

My real contribution is to note that this challenges why unbundling and bundling happens at all. The main idea behind why we sway between bundled and unbundled products is the [underlying technology](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling#:\~:text=a%20lot%20of%20it%20is%20based%20on%20the%20underlying%20technology%20change). Marc Andreesen, co-founder of a16z and of [Mosaic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(web_browser)), the first web browser, talks through the concept of the newspaper:

> `â€œThe newspaper bundle, the idea of this slug of news and sports scores and classifieds and stock quotes that arrives once a day was a consequence of the printing plant, of the distribution network for newspapers using trucks and newsstands, and the famous newspaper delivery boy. That newspaper bundle was based on the distribution technology of a time and place.`
>
> `When the distribution technology changed with the internet, there was going to be the great unwind, and then the great rebundle, in the form of Google and Facebook and Twitter.â€`

This is certainly true: we could only put [live events on Twitch](https://youtu.be/TCPjk8Tpb5c?t=1025) after network infrastructure made it cheap enough to broadcast live video around the world.

But itâ€™s no coincidence that physical businesses are unbundling at the same time as digital ones, despite relying on different technologies, and often very little tech at all. Neither technology nor innovations built upon it come from magic: what consumers *actually want* plays a key role; today itâ€™s driven by the niche market vibe shift.

Why? Well first, consumer demand fosters technological innovation. I took a cursory glance at solar panels [last month](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/podcast-discussion-negotiating-our?s=w#:\~:text=we%E2%80%99re%20already%20on%20the%20way.%20solar%2C%20wind%2C%20fusion%2C%20geothermal%2C%20and%20hydrogen%20energy%20technologies%20have%20all%20advanced%20significantly%20even%20in%20the%20past%20decade.), where growing consumer demand and growing production have *induced* new technologies; if people hadnâ€™t bothered to use streaming services in the early days, there wouldnâ€™t have been the investment that made them possible at scale. Substack was built because its founders [believed](https://every.to/divinations/substack-s-ideology) writers wanted to offer readers deeper value in a specific niche - and that [readers would pay for it](https://twitter.com/hamishmckenzie/status/1532432557513404416) â€“ not due to any new technologies, just due to the niche market vibe shift.

Second, even when this technological innovation happens, there is no rule commanding consumers to use every new use case thatâ€™s suddenly made possible. Google, Facebook, and Twitter all had to create new bundles that people actually wanted to use: do [Google+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google%2B), [Google Answers](http://answers.google.com/answers/faq.html#:\~:text=google%20answers%20was%20an%20experimental%20product%20for%20users%20to%20get%20help%20from%20researchers%20with%20expertise%20in%20online%20searching.), or [Google Notebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Notebook#:\~:text=allowed%20users%20to%20save%20and%20organize%20clips%20of%20information%20while%20conducting%20research%20online) ring a bell?

**I think the reason Iâ€™m seeing more sweetshops around is because of a niche market vibe shift. The technology for serving more niche communities has always existed, but now consumers actually want it. *But what does this mean?***


---

I have two quick points before we move on: why this insight is important and why this shift is happening.

First, understanding that bundling and unbundling cycles sway partly due to social preferences, as well as technology, is important to understanding where these sways stop and start, and how to take advantage of them. If itâ€™s true that people want more meaningful, participatory communities, that tells us a lot more about where the future is going than simply observing the entire possibility space opened up by new technologies. When I looked at those failed Google products, I got the impression that Google - founded by Stanford grads - originally sought to be a lot more academic than it is today, with tools for professional research and note-taking. We can understand that these products failed because they werenâ€™t aligned with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, even though they were technically feasible.

Second, my quick take is that this shift has its roots in societyâ€™s search for reciprocal connection. The 21st century is probably the only century that will ever be worth calling â€˜the internet centuryâ€™ (by the 22nd the internet wonâ€™t be exciting anymore). Todayâ€™s internet is very uni-directional, with big influencers megaphoning to their followers[4](#footnote-4). But people also want to [belong ](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/about#:\~:text=the%20sense%20of%20belonging%20that%20humans%20inherently%20desire)to something, and as I wrote a few months ago, building connections *[within](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/leading-movements-communicating-change?s=w#:\~:text=so%20build%20connections-,within,-your%20movement)* your community makes it so much more fulfilling. You feel youâ€™re really participating, and this is really why I go to the sweet shop. Society just invented the internet, and is searching for meaning. Also [G](https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/12/great-recession-still-with-us/547268/).[F](https://www.bruegel.org/2018/10/ten-years-after-the-crisis-the-wests-failure-pushing-china-towards-state-capitalism/).[C](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227439075_THE_IMPACT_OF_THE_ECONOMIC_CRISIS_ON_CULTURE).

![This is a great time to take a break, maybe stretch your legs, and share with a friend! (Kevin Huynh)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7pYdkgZ_QQytonD6G7z0-.webp?height=796&width=1456)


---

The rest of this essay is to explore how this shift is influencing culture. We can think pretty big about *all* the unbundling opportunities new technologies bring: in *[Life After Google](https://www.waterstones.com/book/life-after-google/george-gilder/9781621575764)*, Gilder points out that even money *could* be unbundled, though I donâ€™t think this is on the cards. Itâ€™s possible, but consumers donâ€™t actually want to unbundle money into a store of value, unit of account, and so forth. Very few communities are built simply around money as a tool; everyone will *not* become [currency traders](https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/12/11/bitcoin-ethereum-cryptocurrency-web3-great-protocol-politics/#:\~:text=everyone%20becomes%20a%20foreign-exchange%20trader); a niche canâ€™t be built around something that everyone uses, and most people donâ€™t care.

I want to instead focus on culture, which people care a lot about, and is interesting for many further reasons. It interests me how great cultural contributions both capture some image of society whilst also moving it forward[5](#footnote-5). Culture is also beautifully adaptable and flexible and fluid, changing rapidly and exhibiting immense diversity of contribution and consumption: itâ€™s a *collection of niches*. I expect this vibe shift to play out in culture very soon. (It goes without saying that this will occur on the internet.)

That idea of culture as a collection of niches deserves interrogating: culture is also something that we all share. And sure, there will continue to be big Instagram accounts and large supermarkets; shows and books that everyone talks about and events that unite the masses. But as Rex Woodbury notes: â€œ[Celebrities like (Tom) Cruise are a dying breed](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/cultural-transmission-in-the-internet?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NTcwOTkyMTIsIl8iOiJlcTFDOSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDE2NzYxMywiZXhwIjoxNjU0MTcxMjEzLCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzg1MDAiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.pfK8o_nxyz7FIehX7-CkXaRKa-d0-3YhcJ1I1r_YRkg&s=r#:\~:text=celebrities%20like%20cruise%20are%20a%20dying%20breed)â€[6](#footnote-6). The 2020s will be defined by the â€œ[long tail of creators](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/the-two-way-mirror-of-art-and-technology?s=w#:\~:text=embolden%20the%20long%20tail%20of%20creators)â€, each creating en mass for far smaller communities with much deeper engagement. In the 21st century, we will seek experiences that feel, in some important ways (and not all), totally and emphatically human â€” thatâ€™s why people love [eSports](https://erikhoel.substack.com/p/why-watch-other-people-play-video?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NDUxMzUyMzksIl8iOiJrK0hyQSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDIwNjQ5OSwiZXhwIjoxNjU0MjEwMDk5LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzMyOTk2Iiwic3ViIjoicG9zdC1yZWFjdGlvbiJ9.T5f6CkyK7SFpzLO3nZZ6U2Zudqkkf4npc9ZsqDnSqFg&s=r#:\~:text=as%20totally%20and%20unabashedly%20human); weâ€™re in the moment *with* the players. **For the hobbies and niches that we love, for which weâ€™re far more than mere followers, weâ€™ll find people serving that niche with dedicated communities built around them.**

[Late Checkout](https://latecheckout.studio/about) is an agency that doesnâ€™t deserve the negative tag associated with such companies[7](#footnote-7); they capture the situation perfectly:

> `â€œThe old way of building products was to try and be everything to everyone. Products were chunky, bloated, and didnâ€™t serve the individual or communities.â€`
>
> `â€œPeople want to feel a connection to the products they use. They want the internet to feel human and alive again.â€`

Itâ€™s exciting to see people building the future, and culturally weâ€™re going to see exactly this: **content will be built around niche and dedicated communities with genuine human connection**[8](#footnote-8).


---

## And thus the 1,000 True Fans thesis eventually manifests.

In 2008, Kevin Kelly wrote one of the most seminal contributions in culture tech. The founding editor-in-chief of Wired wrote that, in the internet age:

> `â€œTo make a living as a craftsperson, photographer, musician, designer, author, animator, app maker, entrepreneur, or inventor you need only thousands of true fans.â€`

A thousand dedicated fans who love your niche. Sound familiar? 

So what took so long?

Itâ€™s certainly the case that the technology of the era made this difficult. Kelly hoped that the internet would be the ultimate matchmaker. Bring the creators and the consumers online, and they will find each other. To an extent, they did, especially in the early days of the internet: in 2008, writing about 1000 True Fans looked sensible. But it was still pretty hard: you could publish your own content, but without mass-market services like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, that helped you discover, it was tough to find or be found.

The introduction of these services, monoliths to be, helped in one sense: it was a lot easier for people to find you on the internet. But the price for this matchmaking was almost everything: Facebook and Instagram take almost 100% of all the revenue creators see on their platforms; YouTube takes 45%; Spotify paid an average of merely Â£700 to each artist last year[9](#footnote-9). These monoliths do the matching, but make it virtually unaffordable to create in the first place.

It was a vibe shift, not a technological one, that struck the first blow to this impoverished paradigm. Twitch, Kickstarter, Patreon, Substack, amongst many others, are all services built for creators to cater for the dedicated fans of their niche; all built amidst the community-centric vibe shift born in the 2010s. Well before the 2020 crypto bull run, a16z heralded a [100 True Fans model](https://future.a16z.com/1000-true-fans-try-100/) in 2020[10](#footnote-10), arguing that this was made possible with even more niche services from Podia, Teachable, and Kajabi. (These companies *all* help people sell educational courses, which undermines the argument to an extent, but you only need 250 fans paying Â£20/$25 per month to earn \~3x the average UK salary or [$75,000](https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2019628,00.html#:\~:text=no%20matter%20how%20much%20more), so you get the picture.) **With the alignment of technology and the vibe, the impoverished paradigm of community-stricken creatorship is collapsing.**


---

### Blockchain is a game-changer for this dynamic

*Youâ€™re reading on Mirror, so you probably know all this; you could easily skip to the next phrase in bold.*

In the early 2020s, new technologies like blockchain, distributed ledgers, and cryptocurrencies really came in vogue. A distributed ledger is triple-entry bookkeeping. [Double-entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping) bookkeeping was invented in medieval Italy: two parties to a transaction would both record it, giving you more data about your business and more verifiable figures, making it easier to trade and pursue enterprise.

Eight centuries later, distributed ledgers are triple-entry bookkeeping: as well as the seller and buyer, *every participant in the economy* makes a record of the transaction, and every participant is using the same, enormous, book. Blockchain is the technology of how you add to this book and run software with it, and cryptocurrency is one use case: the ledger essentially records how much currency you own, which everyone verifies. Obviously Iâ€™m simplifying, but Iâ€™ll refer to these technologies as â€˜web3 techsâ€™[11](#footnote-11).

The significance of blockchain becomes clear upon interrogating why Facebook, YouTube, *et al.* can take such high take rates on creators. One side is [discovery](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/infinite-scroll/what-the-creator-economy-promises-and-what-it-actually-does#:\~:text=no%20one%20finds%20a%20person%20on%20patreon%3B%20you%20go%20there%20after%20you%E2%80%99ve%20found%20them): you rarely *find* creators on Patreon. This happens, still, on big social networks. Everyone is on these platforms (well, not Facebook) and when you consume on these platforms frequently, theyâ€™re experts in figuring out what content youâ€™ll click on next; big data, [Markov chains](https://towardsdatascience.com/introduction-to-markov-chains-50da3645a50d#:\~:text=predict%20weather%20for%20days%20to%20come%2C%20based%20on%20what%20the%20current%20weather%20state%20is%20at%20the%20time), etc. There are some problems with this, mainly that you get served addictive content rather than niches that you want to engage deeply in, but generally they do this job pretty well, and web3 techs donâ€™t hugely change this.

But there are a lot of platforms for discovery â€” this isnâ€™t the competitive moat it once was. People use Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, and much more, in addition to the discovery platforms weâ€™ve called out above; as mentioned, most people have moved beyond Facebook. Creators could just move to whichever discovery network takes the smallest cut of their revenue. Apart from one thing: they canâ€™t. Everything youâ€™ve ever uploaded to Spotify and all the followers youâ€™ve earnt on Insta: the discovery platform manages this, and you canâ€™t take your community with you. So itâ€™s impossible to leave without starting all over again. And hence discovery networks [squeeze](https://stratechery.com/2015/niches-problem-subscription-services/) creators for revenue.

And hence, the game-changer. Because just like with your cryptocurrency, you can store your [writing](https://mirror.xyz/), your [music](https://sound.xyz/), your [art](https://opensea.io/), your [videos](https://d.tube/), your [followers](https://lens.xyz/), on a distributed ledger, or â€œon chainâ€. As [LBRY](https://lbry.io/) puts it: â€œLBRY does to publishing what Bitcoin did to money.â€ Just like with your currency, everyone participating in the economy agrees that â€œyes, [Leo](https://app.ens.domains/name/leosn.eth/details), you wrote this blogâ€. Sites like Spotify and Instagram donâ€™t manage your songs and your followers because these songs and follower relationships are stored on chain, and Spotify is reduced to one of many organisations competing to merely display this content in the best way, and help you discover new content as well. Creators are not beholden to any of them â€“ and neither are consumers[12](#footnote-12).

So now the community economy is fully on the way because finally, **dedicated participants in a niche community can meaningfully support their creators**. When people are deeply engaged in something they care about, even the original consumers become contributors, and weâ€™ll start to see vibrant ecosystems formed around niches and creators. Greg Isenberg explores the [Loot ecosystem](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/heres-what-the-future-of-nfts-looks?s=r#:\~:text=it%E2%80%99s%20an%20ecosystem%20not%20just%20an%20nft), an NFT project upon which creators have realised myriad different ideas; [Jenkins the Valet](https://www.jenkinsthevalet.com/how-it-works) is a great example of community-led storytelling, which will become a category-defining cultural genre in the 2020s, on par with â€˜artâ€™ and â€˜literatureâ€™. [Jadyn Violet](https://twitter.com/jadynviolet), a musician, told me that â€œIâ€™ve never got this much interaction on my art before.â€ He's been spending his time building new ideas to engage his community, spending time speaking with his fans, and making more music â€” this is what his fans love him for.

Business people often talk about the Minimum Viable Product your business needs before you start selling. The MVP isnâ€™t dead, but all businesses (not just creators) will soon require a [Minimum Viable Community](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uPRruLfZoU&t=2s) to make a mark in their market[13](#footnote-13).

What will underlie all of these communities are tokens of membership, probably tiered, which tie a community together. Theyâ€™ll be non-fungible, which means theyâ€™ll be unique and personalisable, thus allowing for deeper engagement. **Consumers get dedicated community and deeper value in a niche they care about; creators are finally rewarded fairly for their work.** 

![Tiered NFT collections can help creators build more intimate communities. Everyone wants this; web3 makes it possible. (Peter Yang)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OjR9B7mzwKA76xALqr8qk.png?height=512&width=1167)

## An exciting future, not an Exciting one

In 1999, Excite was a $6.7bn search engine, but collapsed soon after the 2001 dotcom crash. Google was only just getting started, but after aligning with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, became the favoured search engine of billions.

Joe Kraus, the founder of Excite, [explains why](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=i%20went%20to%20revisit%20joe%20kraus): Excite had been a 20th century company, targeting revenue from the top ten American companies, as media businesses had been doing for decades. Meanwhile, Google focused on attracting advertisers â€” and millions of them. Why did this work? *â€œThe 20th century was about dozens of markets of millions of consumers. **The 21st century is about millions of markets of dozens of consumers.**â€*


---

*Hopefully that didnâ€™t actually feel like 3,000 words; Iâ€™d love it if you were to [subscribe](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/subscribe) or mint one of 5 editions.*


---

`Image credits: HelloDorking; Kevin Huynh; Peter Yang`

***Footnotes:***

[1](#footnote-anchor-1) I donâ€™t have the percentage figures for the change in sweetshops and clothing stores, Iâ€™m sorry.

[2](#footnote-anchor-2) Other blogging platforms are available, including this one, but theyâ€™re still *built* for writers; Iâ€™m testing the beta of [Nuance](http://nuance.xyz/).

[3](#footnote-anchor-3) Stratechery anticipated this for (cable) TV in [2013](https://stratechery.com/2013/the-jobs-tv-does/#:\~:text=the%20jobs%20tv%20has%20traditionally%20done%20include) and watched it happen in [2017](https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/#:\~:text=tv%20is%20broken%20up%20into%20the%20different%20%E2%80%9Cjobs%E2%80%9D%20it%20has%20traditionally%20done): TV used to keep us **informed**, **educate** us, show **live events**, tell **stories**, and provide **escapism**. But now we get our information from Google; our education from YouTube, Coursera, or Masterworks; our live events from Twitch; our story-telling from Netflix; and our escapism from social media. Itâ€™s not as neat as this of course: in reality, everything just exploded into a plethora of mainly mobile options; but unbundling is happening.

[4](#footnote-anchor-4) I number crunched some of the Instagram follower stats [here](https://mention.com/en/reports/instagram/followers/) and would estimate that of all the follower-followee relationships, the largest 1% of accounts receive about 50% of all following relationships.

[5](#footnote-anchor-5) Iâ€™m undecided and unclear on what this means for â€˜greatâ€™ or â€˜classicâ€™ cultural contributions. If a great cultural contribution captures an image of society, but also moves it on, how can it be classic, if being classic is continuing to capture that image of society: hasnâ€™t society moved on and been influenced by your contribution? 

[6](#footnote-anchor-6) Woodbury is mainly making the argument that it is specifically â€œa 20th-century culture centered around white leading menâ€ that is dying, but whilst itâ€™s true that celebrities are becoming more diverse, whatâ€™s more important is that theyâ€™re becoming less relevant. The social media era is dying; the social community era is coming.

[7](#footnote-anchor-7) Itâ€™s ironic that in principle â€˜agencyâ€™ is the most important thing in the world, whilst â€˜agenciesâ€™ that help brands and creators reach their fans are typically seen as vultures.

[8](#footnote-anchor-8) I also expect niche and tailored content that is ***emphatically artificial***: a further implication of this, from the unrelated and sufficient cause of AI too, is that individuals will asymptote towards consuming cultural content that is tailored just for them: *an audience of one*. As artificial intelligence (which was also covered [last month](http://The asymptote we reach is that for most people, most of the time, their reading and viewing material is created just for them)) gets more able to accurately predict our interests and preferences at a subtle scale, we get to a world in which content is designed â€“ no, generated â€“ to appeal specifically to us. GPT-3 is an OpenAI algorithm that can conduct incredibly lifelike conversation (at times). [The Next Web](https://thenextweb.com/news/openai-punished-dev-used-gpt-3-to-resurrect-dead-ethics) covers the story of one developer who used the algorithm to sell bots that spoke with the *individual personalities* of an individual chosen by a customer, including dead relatives. As always, there are challenges that accompany change, as well as opportunities; AI will continue to develop, but the risk and threat of AI trained to stimulate and manipulate us need to be managed. *Further reading: [The Diff](https://www.thediff.co/p/what-happens-when-most-media-is-produced?s=r) explores this idea from a more financial perspective; the [NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/27/1088140809/fake-linkedin-profiles) illustrates a perfect example, with fake LinkedIn profiles generated explicitly to pique your interest; [Tyler Cowen](https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/04/when-your-bot-is-better-than-you.html) touches on the issue from the other perspective, that of the person using the bot.*

[9](#footnote-anchor-9) Sources: Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube stats [here](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/); in 2021 Spotify paid [$7bn](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) to [8 million](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) creators, which is $875 or Â£700 (slightly higher than the claim in the a16z source above).

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for â€˜web3 in vogueâ€™ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldnâ€™t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) Iâ€™m simplifying a lot; this isnâ€™t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, itâ€™s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, itâ€™s every computer server; and itâ€™s not every computer server, itâ€™s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterinâ€™s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation â€” which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I donâ€™t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Community and the niche market vibe shift
body:
***Brands and creators that build for niche and dedicated communities will win the 2020s.***

Iâ€™ve seen a lot more sweetshops around recently. Specifically, these Victorian-themed tuckshops and sweet connoisseurs, plucked from two hundred years prior and plopped in the middle of a high street that doesnâ€™t quite know how to welcome its new tenant. One of the sweet shops near me plasters â€˜Toys, Trains, Treatsâ€ on dated storefront panelling; itâ€™s the shop you thought your grandparents went to when they were young, except the steam trains on sale are battery powered.

This wasnâ€™t just a Baaderâ€“Meinhof [phenomenon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency_illusion), where upon seeing something once you perceive it everywhere. During the first year of the pandemic, an extra [73](https://www.mylondon.news/news/uk-world-news/i-visited-londons-new-dangerous-22961908#:\~:text=73%20more%20sweet%20shops%20in%20the%20uk%20compared%20with%202020) sweetshops popped up in the UK, net, according to the Local Data Company. Thatâ€™s not a huge number, but itâ€™s pretty significant given the broader lockdown context; the total number of clothing shops fell by 1,236 in the same period[1](#footnote-1). The shop near me was set up in September â€˜21. It begs the question: whatâ€™s so special about sweet shops?

I had spent my Saturday morning at Waterstones buying some books, at the sweet shop questioning the shop assistant, and now Iâ€™m writing about it on Substack. In days gone by, I would have bought my physical items at Sainsburyâ€™s and, in comparison to today, where I have my Substack and my main [website](https://www.leonasskau.co.uk/), all my digital publishing would be through the same technology stack, probably Wordpress.

Sweets are nice, but the real difference is the existence of a shop that will focus all of its resources on their specific niche product. I bought some weird caramel chocolate flakes that defy description, but they were excellent. I certainly paid a premium, but next time I want sweets, Iâ€™ll go there again, because *they know their product*; I just bought what the shop assistant recommended. At Waterstoneâ€™s, I picked up [Train Dreams](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/13/train-dreams-denis-johnson-review) because I told the manager I was after contemporary fiction; I use Substack because itâ€™s built for writers[2](#footnote-2). **What makes these businesses special is that they serve *niche markets in which they can give people much deeper value.***

![I mean, you get what Iâ€™m saying, despite the weird animojis, right? (HelloDorking)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xRINH9-26W7ZvCggFpXtm.jpeg?height=2438&width=3024)

## Unbundling into niches

Bundling and unbundling are [not new concepts](https://hbr.org/1999/03/unbundling-the-corporation). Itâ€™s a pretty simple convection model: you start with a business, over time you add more products, services, and features, and then you get bloated, do everything â€˜kinda wellâ€™, until a niche competitor comes along and does *one* of your services *really really well*, and bit by bit you get pieced apart. The [complexity convection](https://every.to/divinations/complexity-convection-765851) is a pattern that cannot be unseen. 

People have observed this happening to our contemporary digital landscape for about a decade, beginning in practice much earlier. Craigslist was [unbundled](https://thegongshow.tumblr.com/post/345941486/the-spawn-of-craigslist-like-most-vcs-that-focus) into many things, including Reddit, which is now being [unbundled](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/the-guide-to-unbundling-reddit?s=r) into many more things, like Nextdoor. In the language of [a16z](https://a16z.com/2019/09/11/platforms-verticals-unbundling/), the famed tech investors: platforms get unbundled into verticals, which turn into platforms, at which point the cycle resumes, and all of a sudden Iâ€™ve turned into a strategy writer[3](#footnote-3). 

Iâ€™m not the first to herald this unbundling in the physical world either. Peter Day [wrote](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=Economy%2C%20%20almost%20a,speed%20and%20efficiency.) an excellent essay predicting â€œthe heartbeat economy, almost a concierge approach to customers,â€ in 2013:

> `â€œThis would be a worryingly intimate relationship for many businesses, but one which might provide a new kind of rewarding marketplace if they dared to be far closer to their customers' individuality.â€`

He wrote about it in the BBC, but today he would write on his own blog.

My real contribution is to note that this challenges why unbundling and bundling happens at all. The main idea behind why we sway between bundled and unbundled products is the [underlying technology](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling#:\~:text=a%20lot%20of%20it%20is%20based%20on%20the%20underlying%20technology%20change). Marc Andreesen, co-founder of a16z and of [Mosaic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(web_browser)), the first web browser, talks through the concept of the newspaper:

> `â€œThe newspaper bundle, the idea of this slug of news and sports scores and classifieds and stock quotes that arrives once a day was a consequence of the printing plant, of the distribution network for newspapers using trucks and newsstands, and the famous newspaper delivery boy. That newspaper bundle was based on the distribution technology of a time and place.`
>
> `When the distribution technology changed with the internet, there was going to be the great unwind, and then the great rebundle, in the form of Google and Facebook and Twitter.â€`

This is certainly true: we could only put [live events on Twitch](https://youtu.be/TCPjk8Tpb5c?t=1025) after network infrastructure made it cheap enough to broadcast live video around the world.

But itâ€™s no coincidence that physical businesses are unbundling at the same time as digital ones, despite relying on different technologies, and often very little tech at all. Neither technology nor innovations built upon it come from magic: what consumers *actually want* plays a key role; today itâ€™s driven by the niche market vibe shift.

Why? Well first, consumer demand fosters technological innovation. I took a cursory glance at solar panels [last month](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/podcast-discussion-negotiating-our?s=w#:\~:text=we%E2%80%99re%20already%20on%20the%20way.%20solar%2C%20wind%2C%20fusion%2C%20geothermal%2C%20and%20hydrogen%20energy%20technologies%20have%20all%20advanced%20significantly%20even%20in%20the%20past%20decade.), where growing consumer demand and growing production have *induced* new technologies; if people hadnâ€™t bothered to use streaming services in the early days, there wouldnâ€™t have been the investment that made them possible at scale. Substack was built because its founders [believed](https://every.to/divinations/substack-s-ideology) writers wanted to offer readers deeper value in a specific niche - and that [readers would pay for it](https://twitter.com/hamishmckenzie/status/1532432557513404416) â€“ not due to any new technologies, just due to the niche market vibe shift.

Second, even when this technological innovation happens, there is no rule commanding consumers to use every new use case thatâ€™s suddenly made possible. Google, Facebook, and Twitter all had to create new bundles that people actually wanted to use: do [Google+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google%2B), [Google Answers](http://answers.google.com/answers/faq.html#:\~:text=google%20answers%20was%20an%20experimental%20product%20for%20users%20to%20get%20help%20from%20researchers%20with%20expertise%20in%20online%20searching.), or [Google Notebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Notebook#:\~:text=allowed%20users%20to%20save%20and%20organize%20clips%20of%20information%20while%20conducting%20research%20online) ring a bell?

**I think the reason Iâ€™m seeing more sweetshops around is because of a niche market vibe shift. The technology for serving more niche communities has always existed, but now consumers actually want it. *But what does this mean?***


---

I have two quick points before we move on: why this insight is important and why this shift is happening.

First, understanding that bundling and unbundling cycles sway partly due to social preferences, as well as technology, is important to understanding where these sways stop and start, and how to take advantage of them. If itâ€™s true that people want more meaningful, participatory communities, that tells us a lot more about where the future is going than simply observing the entire possibility space opened up by new technologies. When I looked at those failed Google products, I got the impression that Google - founded by Stanford grads - originally sought to be a lot more academic than it is today, with tools for professional research and note-taking. We can understand that these products failed because they werenâ€™t aligned with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, even though they were technically feasible.

Second, my quick take is that this shift has its roots in societyâ€™s search for reciprocal connection. The 21st century is probably the only century that will ever be worth calling â€˜the internet centuryâ€™ (by the 22nd the internet wonâ€™t be exciting anymore). Todayâ€™s internet is very uni-directional, with big influencers megaphoning to their followers[4](#footnote-4). But people also want to [belong ](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/about#:\~:text=the%20sense%20of%20belonging%20that%20humans%20inherently%20desire)to something, and as I wrote a few months ago, building connections *[within](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/leading-movements-communicating-change?s=w#:\~:text=so%20build%20connections-,within,-your%20movement)* your community makes it so much more fulfilling. You feel youâ€™re really participating, and this is really why I go to the sweet shop. Society just invented the internet, and is searching for meaning. Also [G](https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/12/great-recession-still-with-us/547268/).[F](https://www.bruegel.org/2018/10/ten-years-after-the-crisis-the-wests-failure-pushing-china-towards-state-capitalism/).[C](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227439075_THE_IMPACT_OF_THE_ECONOMIC_CRISIS_ON_CULTURE).

![This is a great time to take a break, maybe stretch your legs, and share with a friend! (Kevin Huynh)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7pYdkgZ_QQytonD6G7z0-.webp?height=796&width=1456)


---

The rest of this essay is to explore how this shift is influencing culture. We can think pretty big about *all* the unbundling opportunities new technologies bring: in *[Life After Google](https://www.waterstones.com/book/life-after-google/george-gilder/9781621575764)*, Gilder points out that even money *could* be unbundled, though I donâ€™t think this is on the cards. Itâ€™s possible, but consumers donâ€™t actually want to unbundle money into a store of value, unit of account, and so forth. Very few communities are built simply around money as a tool; everyone will *not* become [currency traders](https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/12/11/bitcoin-ethereum-cryptocurrency-web3-great-protocol-politics/#:\~:text=everyone%20becomes%20a%20foreign-exchange%20trader); a niche canâ€™t be built around something that everyone uses, and most people donâ€™t care.

I want to instead focus on culture, which people care a lot about, and is interesting for many further reasons. It interests me how great cultural contributions both capture some image of society whilst also moving it forward[5](#footnote-5). Culture is also beautifully adaptable and flexible and fluid, changing rapidly and exhibiting immense diversity of contribution and consumption: itâ€™s a *collection of niches*. I expect this vibe shift to play out in culture very soon. (It goes without saying that this will occur on the internet.)

That idea of culture as a collection of niches deserves interrogating: culture is also something that we all share. And sure, there will continue to be big Instagram accounts and large supermarkets; shows and books that everyone talks about and events that unite the masses. But as Rex Woodbury notes: â€œ[Celebrities like (Tom) Cruise are a dying breed](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/cultural-transmission-in-the-internet?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NTcwOTkyMTIsIl8iOiJlcTFDOSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDE2NzYxMywiZXhwIjoxNjU0MTcxMjEzLCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzg1MDAiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.pfK8o_nxyz7FIehX7-CkXaRKa-d0-3YhcJ1I1r_YRkg&s=r#:\~:text=celebrities%20like%20cruise%20are%20a%20dying%20breed)â€[6](#footnote-6). The 2020s will be defined by the â€œ[long tail of creators](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/the-two-way-mirror-of-art-and-technology?s=w#:\~:text=embolden%20the%20long%20tail%20of%20creators)â€, each creating en mass for far smaller communities with much deeper engagement. In the 21st century, we will seek experiences that feel, in some important ways (and not all), totally and emphatically human â€” thatâ€™s why people love [eSports](https://erikhoel.substack.com/p/why-watch-other-people-play-video?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NDUxMzUyMzksIl8iOiJrK0hyQSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDIwNjQ5OSwiZXhwIjoxNjU0MjEwMDk5LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzMyOTk2Iiwic3ViIjoicG9zdC1yZWFjdGlvbiJ9.T5f6CkyK7SFpzLO3nZZ6U2Zudqkkf4npc9ZsqDnSqFg&s=r#:\~:text=as%20totally%20and%20unabashedly%20human); weâ€™re in the moment *with* the players. **For the hobbies and niches that we love, for which weâ€™re far more than mere followers, weâ€™ll find people serving that niche with dedicated communities built around them.**

[Late Checkout](https://latecheckout.studio/about) is an agency that doesnâ€™t deserve the negative tag associated with such companies[7](#footnote-7); they capture the situation perfectly:

> `â€œThe old way of building products was to try and be everything to everyone. Products were chunky, bloated, and didnâ€™t serve the individual or communities.â€`
>
> `â€œPeople want to feel a connection to the products they use. They want the internet to feel human and alive again.â€`

Itâ€™s exciting to see people building the future, and culturally weâ€™re going to see exactly this: **content will be built around niche and dedicated communities with genuine human connection**[8](#footnote-8).


---

## And thus the 1,000 True Fans thesis eventually manifests.

In 2008, Kevin Kelly wrote one of the most seminal contributions in culture tech. The founding editor-in-chief of Wired wrote that, in the internet age:

> `â€œTo make a living as a craftsperson, photographer, musician, designer, author, animator, app maker, entrepreneur, or inventor you need only thousands of true fans.â€`

A thousand dedicated fans who love your niche. Sound familiar? 

So what took so long?

Itâ€™s certainly the case that the technology of the era made this difficult. Kelly hoped that the internet would be the ultimate matchmaker. Bring the creators and the consumers online, and they will find each other. To an extent, they did, especially in the early days of the internet: in 2008, writing about 1000 True Fans looked sensible. But it was still pretty hard: you could publish your own content, but without mass-market services like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, that helped you discover, it was tough to find or be found.

The introduction of these services, monoliths to be, helped in one sense: it was a lot easier for people to find you on the internet. But the price for this matchmaking was almost everything: Facebook and Instagram take almost 100% of all the revenue creators see on their platforms; YouTube takes 45%; Spotify paid an average of merely Â£700 to each artist last year[9](#footnote-9). These monoliths do the matching, but make it virtually unaffordable to create in the first place.

It was a vibe shift, not a technological one, that struck the first blow to this impoverished paradigm. Twitch, Kickstarter, Patreon, Substack, amongst many others, are all services built for creators to cater for the dedicated fans of their niche; all built amidst the community-centric vibe shift born in the 2010s. Well before the 2020 crypto bull run, a16z heralded a [100 True Fans model](https://future.a16z.com/1000-true-fans-try-100/) in 2020[10](#footnote-10), arguing that this was made possible with even more niche services from Podia, Teachable, and Kajabi. (These companies *all* help people sell educational courses, which undermines the argument to an extent, but you only need 250 fans paying Â£20/$25 per month to earn \~3x the average UK salary or [$75,000](https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2019628,00.html#:\~:text=no%20matter%20how%20much%20more), so you get the picture.) **With the alignment of technology and the vibe, the impoverished paradigm of community-stricken creatorship is collapsing.**


---

### Blockchain is a game-changer for this dynamic

*Youâ€™re reading on Mirror, so you probably know all this; you could easily skip to the next phrase in bold.*

In the early 2020s, new technologies like blockchain, distributed ledgers, and cryptocurrencies really came in vogue. A distributed ledger is triple-entry bookkeeping. [Double-entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping) bookkeeping was invented in medieval Italy: two parties to a transaction would both record it, giving you more data about your business and more verifiable figures, making it easier to trade and pursue enterprise.

Eight centuries later, distributed ledgers are triple-entry bookkeeping: as well as the seller and buyer, *every participant in the economy* makes a record of the transaction, and every participant is using the same, enormous, book. Blockchain is the technology of how you add to this book and run software with it, and cryptocurrency is one use case: the ledger essentially records how much currency you own, which everyone verifies. Obviously Iâ€™m simplifying, but Iâ€™ll refer to these technologies as â€˜web3 techsâ€™[11](#footnote-11).

The significance of blockchain becomes clear upon interrogating why Facebook, YouTube, *et al.* can take such high take rates on creators. One side is [discovery](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/infinite-scroll/what-the-creator-economy-promises-and-what-it-actually-does#:\~:text=no%20one%20finds%20a%20person%20on%20patreon%3B%20you%20go%20there%20after%20you%E2%80%99ve%20found%20them): you rarely *find* creators on Patreon. This happens, still, on big social networks. Everyone is on these platforms (well, not Facebook) and when you consume on these platforms frequently, theyâ€™re experts in figuring out what content youâ€™ll click on next; big data, [Markov chains](https://towardsdatascience.com/introduction-to-markov-chains-50da3645a50d#:\~:text=predict%20weather%20for%20days%20to%20come%2C%20based%20on%20what%20the%20current%20weather%20state%20is%20at%20the%20time), etc. There are some problems with this, mainly that you get served addictive content rather than niches that you want to engage deeply in, but generally they do this job pretty well, and web3 techs donâ€™t hugely change this.

But there are a lot of platforms for discovery â€” this isnâ€™t the competitive moat it once was. People use Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, and much more, in addition to the discovery platforms weâ€™ve called out above; as mentioned, most people have moved beyond Facebook. Creators could just move to whichever discovery network takes the smallest cut of their revenue. Apart from one thing: they canâ€™t. Everything youâ€™ve ever uploaded to Spotify and all the followers youâ€™ve earnt on Insta: the discovery platform manages this, and you canâ€™t take your community with you. So itâ€™s impossible to leave without starting all over again. And hence discovery networks [squeeze](https://stratechery.com/2015/niches-problem-subscription-services/) creators for revenue.

And hence, the game-changer. Because just like with your cryptocurrency, you can store your [writing](https://mirror.xyz/), your [music](https://sound.xyz/), your [art](https://opensea.io/), your [videos](https://d.tube/), your [followers](https://lens.xyz/), on a distributed ledger, or â€œon chainâ€. As [LBRY](https://lbry.io/) puts it: â€œLBRY does to publishing what Bitcoin did to money.â€ Just like with your currency, everyone participating in the economy agrees that â€œyes, [Leo](https://app.ens.domains/name/leosn.eth/details), you wrote this blogâ€. Sites like Spotify and Instagram donâ€™t manage your songs and your followers because these songs and follower relationships are stored on chain, and Spotify is reduced to one of many organisations competing to merely display this content in the best way, and help you discover new content as well. Creators are not beholden to any of them â€“ and neither are consumers[12](#footnote-12).

So now the community economy is fully on the way because finally, **dedicated participants in a niche community can meaningfully support their creators**. When people are deeply engaged in something they care about, even the original consumers become contributors, and weâ€™ll start to see vibrant ecosystems formed around niches and creators. Greg Isenberg explores the [Loot ecosystem](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/heres-what-the-future-of-nfts-looks?s=r#:\~:text=it%E2%80%99s%20an%20ecosystem%20not%20just%20an%20nft), an NFT project upon which creators have realised myriad different ideas; [Jenkins the Valet](https://www.jenkinsthevalet.com/how-it-works) is a great example of community-led storytelling, which will become a category-defining cultural genre in the 2020s, on par with â€˜artâ€™ and â€˜literatureâ€™. [Jadyn Violet](https://twitter.com/jadynviolet), a musician, told me that â€œIâ€™ve never got this much interaction on my art before.â€ He's been spending his time building new ideas to engage his community, spending time speaking with his fans, and making more music â€” this is what his fans love him for.

Business people often talk about the Minimum Viable Product your business needs before you start selling. The MVP isnâ€™t dead, but all businesses (not just creators) will soon require a [Minimum Viable Community](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uPRruLfZoU&t=2s) to make a mark in their market[13](#footnote-13).

What will underlie all of these communities are tokens of membership, probably tiered, which tie a community together. Theyâ€™ll be non-fungible, which means theyâ€™ll be unique and personalisable, thus allowing for deeper engagement. **Consumers get dedicated community and deeper value in a niche they care about; creators are finally rewarded fairly for their work.** 

![Tiered NFT collections can help creators build more intimate communities. Everyone wants this; web3 makes it possible. (Peter Yang)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OjR9B7mzwKA76xALqr8qk.png?height=512&width=1167)

## An exciting future, not an Exciting one

In 1999, Excite was a $6.7bn search engine, but collapsed soon after the 2001 dotcom crash. Google was only just getting started, but after aligning with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, became the favoured search engine of billions.

Joe Kraus, the founder of Excite, [explains why](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=i%20went%20to%20revisit%20joe%20kraus): Excite had been a 20th century company, targeting revenue from the top ten American companies, as media businesses had been doing for decades. Meanwhile, Google focused on attracting advertisers â€” and millions of them. Why did this work? *â€œThe 20th century was about dozens of markets of millions of consumers. **The 21st century is about millions of markets of dozens of consumers.**â€*


---

*Hopefully that didnâ€™t actually feel like 3,000 words; Iâ€™d love it if you were to [subscribe](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/subscribe) for free or mint one of 5 editions.*


---

`Image credits: HelloDorking; Kevin Huynh; Peter Yang`

***Footnotes:***

[1](#footnote-anchor-1) I donâ€™t have the percentage figures for the change in sweetshops and clothing stores, Iâ€™m sorry.

[2](#footnote-anchor-2) Other blogging platforms are available, including this one, but theyâ€™re still *built* for writers; Iâ€™m testing the beta of [Nuance](http://nuance.xyz/).

[3](#footnote-anchor-3) Stratechery anticipated this for (cable) TV in [2013](https://stratechery.com/2013/the-jobs-tv-does/#:\~:text=the%20jobs%20tv%20has%20traditionally%20done%20include) and watched it happen in [2017](https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/#:\~:text=tv%20is%20broken%20up%20into%20the%20different%20%E2%80%9Cjobs%E2%80%9D%20it%20has%20traditionally%20done): TV used to keep us **informed**, **educate** us, show **live events**, tell **stories**, and provide **escapism**. But now we get our information from Google; our education from YouTube, Coursera, or Masterworks; our live events from Twitch; our story-telling from Netflix; and our escapism from social media. Itâ€™s not as neat as this of course: in reality, everything just exploded into a plethora of mainly mobile options; but unbundling is happening.

[4](#footnote-anchor-4) I number crunched some of the Instagram follower stats [here](https://mention.com/en/reports/instagram/followers/) and would estimate that of all the follower-followee relationships, the largest 1% of accounts receive about 50% of all following relationships.

[5](#footnote-anchor-5) Iâ€™m undecided and unclear on what this means for â€˜greatâ€™ or â€˜classicâ€™ cultural contributions. If a great cultural contribution captures an image of society, but also moves it on, how can it be classic, if being classic is continuing to capture that image of society: hasnâ€™t society moved on and been influenced by your contribution? 

[6](#footnote-anchor-6) Woodbury is mainly making the argument that it is specifically â€œa 20th-century culture centered around white leading menâ€ that is dying, but whilst itâ€™s true that celebrities are becoming more diverse, whatâ€™s more important is that theyâ€™re becoming less relevant. The social media era is dying; the social community era is coming.

[7](#footnote-anchor-7) Itâ€™s ironic that in principle â€˜agencyâ€™ is the most important thing in the world, whilst â€˜agenciesâ€™ that help brands and creators reach their fans are typically seen as vultures.

[8](#footnote-anchor-8) I also expect niche and tailored content that is ***emphatically artificial***: a further implication of this, from the unrelated and sufficient cause of AI too, is that individuals will asymptote towards consuming cultural content that is tailored just for them: *an audience of one*. As artificial intelligence (which was also covered [last month](http://The asymptote we reach is that for most people, most of the time, their reading and viewing material is created just for them)) gets more able to accurately predict our interests and preferences at a subtle scale, we get to a world in which content is designed â€“ no, generated â€“ to appeal specifically to us. GPT-3 is an OpenAI algorithm that can conduct incredibly lifelike conversation (at times). [The Next Web](https://thenextweb.com/news/openai-punished-dev-used-gpt-3-to-resurrect-dead-ethics) covers the story of one developer who used the algorithm to sell bots that spoke with the *individual personalities* of an individual chosen by a customer, including dead relatives. As always, there are challenges that accompany change, as well as opportunities; AI will continue to develop, but the risk and threat of AI trained to stimulate and manipulate us need to be managed. *Further reading: [The Diff](https://www.thediff.co/p/what-happens-when-most-media-is-produced?s=r) explores this idea from a more financial perspective; the [NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/27/1088140809/fake-linkedin-profiles) illustrates a perfect example, with fake LinkedIn profiles generated explicitly to pique your interest; [Tyler Cowen](https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/04/when-your-bot-is-better-than-you.html) touches on the issue from the other perspective, that of the person using the bot.*
